docs.lead_paragraph: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not. The debate over health care has consumed much of the 1990's, and the central issue remains: Nearly 43 million Americans are uninsured.

headline.main: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions

docs.lead_paragraph: With Senate races tightening before Tuesday's elections, Democrats seem more likely than they were three weeks ago to pick up at least two seats, and possibly the five they need to reclaim the chamber. Seven Republican seats are vulnerable, while two seats controlled by Democrats are in serious danger of turning over, say nonpartisan election watchers as well as senators and aides who are watching the campaigns most closely.

headline.main: Democrats Given a Shot At Regaining a Majority

docs.abstract: Democrats appear to have chance of regaining control of Senate as several races tighten; analysis of contests in key states; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1983, when the Seth Thomas clock factory closed for good in the Naugatuck Valley town of Thomaston, the workers from the plant carried a bier bearing an elegant mantel clock through the streets in a mock funeral. Then they burned it -- a measure of their contempt for a company that was no longer owned by the family that gave Thomaston its name, but had been bought by a multinational conglomerate and then shut down. The 1980's marked the de-industrialization of the Naugatuck River Valley, which had been one of the ''most industrialized places on Earth'', according to the Connecticut historian Jeremy Brecher. Factories were built throughout the 19th century all along the river, which provided water power and a convenient way to dispose of wastes. The valley had been the worldwide center of the brass industry, with factories like Plume & Atwood turning out brass parts for Seth Thomas timepieces. But in the last quarter of the 20th century the factories closed down, leaving thousands of workers jobless, the Naugatuck River polluted and the land on which the factories sat contaminated by toxic chemicals.

headline.main: Factory Is Reborn in a Once Busy Valley

docs.abstract: Article on revival of factories along Connecticut's Naugatuck River which closed in 1980's; Naugatuck Valley Brownfields Pilot was created in 1996 to clean up and revive about 100 abandoned factory sites known or suspected to contain toxic substances; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE 42 million Americans are without health insurance, the plight of those who work for small businesses is among the most vexing. Many candidates for public office have taken on the issue this year but have offered limited proposals.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer column notes high cost is key factor barring small businesses from providing health insurance for workers; cites success of innovative Muskegon, Mich, program; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Walk in Deidra Everett's shoes a moment: You know that you dress nicely; that you are well-spoken; that you are clean and friendly and funny and smart. Yet when you go for a job interview, your potential employer's eyes tend to sweep your person and fill with horror. You can joke about it -- ''the look'' -- but it has happened so many times that you have almost given up. The unemployment rate in Massachusetts is under 3 percent. Your office administration skills are in desperate demand. But you, as you are often reminded by stares and gibes from strangers, are fat. Fat.

headline.main: Fat People Say an Intolerant World Condemns Them on First Sight

docs.abstract: Article in series The Fat Epidemic explains stigma suffered by fat people; people like Deidra Everett and Elizabeth Fisher describe school, job and social rejections, and even, in Fisher's case, having to campaign to require car makers to offer seat belt extenders; photos; question of whether obesity should be considered disability under Federal law discussed; San Francisco is, for now, one of very few jurisdictions with anti-discrimination ordinance in place (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly 14 years, Guy J. Velella has been the most unlikely of kingpins: an influential Republican state senator in the Bronx, New York City's most Democratic borough; an amiable politician to whom even the state's Democrats went for counsel or support. But if he has been something of a curiosity in the Bronx, because of his party affiliation, Mr. Velella has also been every bit the classic Albany operator. He has delivered millions of government dollars to his Senate district, dispensed patronage without apology, recognized the powers of incumbency in state politics, and made his re-election more a foregone conclusion than a serious contest.

headline.main: G.O.P. Stalwart in Bronx Now Looks Vulnerable

docs.abstract: Guy J Velella, Republican state senator from Bronx and lower Westchester for 14 years, faces difficult challege from Lorraine Coyle Koppell, who has made Velella's ethics centerpiece of her campaign; he is being investigated by Manhattan district attorney's office to determine whether he took money from contractor for help in landing bridge-painting contract; Koppell contends that Valella is too conservative, and that more money is needed from Albany to improve schools and make health care more accessible; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When executives and lobbyists from the biotechnology industry visit Capitol Hill these days, they are often given unsolicited advice: distance yourselves, they are told, from big pharmaceutical companies, which have become public villains in the debate over rising drug prices. Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means health subcommittee, even told biotechnology executives to pick a public fight with ''Big Pharma'' on a prominent issue, according to industry executives who met with him.

headline.main: Protecting a Favorable Image; Biotechnology Concerns in Quandary Over Drug Giants

docs.abstract: Drug industry, fearing government regulation of prescription drug prices, has spent heavily lately to influence candidates, legislators and general public; big pharmaceutical companies would like to enlist more politically appealing biotechnology companies in their fight against Medicare drug prescription benefit that they say would eventually lead to price controls on drugs; drug industry, in effort to overcome its tarnished position, has spent $230 million in last two years on lobbying, image advertising and campaign contributions; Repr Bill Thomas, California Republican and chairman of House Ways and Means health subcommittee, is urging biotechnology executives to pick fight with giant drug companies; graphs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: When executives and lobbyists from the biotechnology industry visit Capitol Hill these days, they are often given unsolicited advice: distance yourselves, they are told, from big pharmaceutical companies, which have become public villains in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The common wisdom about Congress, repeated in news reports and accepted as truth at foreign embassies and in graduate seminars, is that its members are homebound and uninterested in the world. And the statistic most often cited to back up this wisdom is that only half even hold a passport. This portrait of Congress, especially the House of Representatives, as an inward-looking institution grew largely out of the Republican revolution of 1994 led by Newt Gingrich. It was a reputation that took hold quickly and was cemented early this year when Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, declared that ''a shockingly large number of American members of Congress don't hold a passport.''

headline.main: Insular Congress Appears to Be Myth

docs.abstract: Vast majority of members of Congress hold passports and use them, traveling overseas at least twice a year on trips that are largely business with some pleasure; nearly one-third of them have studied or worked abroad, and one in five claims to speak foreign language will enough to conduct business beyond America's borders; these statistics seem to contradict popular notion that members of Congress are homebound and uninterested in world; but statistics cannot serve as indicator of how any member of Congress is likely to vote on issues of foreign or national security (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell slightly, but the results still surpassed Wall Street estimates as its health care business improved. Profit from the health care business rose 17 percent, to $200 million, as the company increased premium revenue 12 percent by adding one million customers and raising rates. The medical loss ratio -- the share of every premium dollar that pays for medical costs -- narrowed to 83.8 cents from 85.5 cents a year earlier for Cigna's health maintenance organizations.
docs.abstract: Cigna Corp says profit from health care business rose 17 percent in third quarter, to $200 million as company increased premium revenue 12 percent; profit from continuing operations fell to $281 million from $285 million a year earlier; revenue rose 7.2 percent, to $5.03 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, this city of gleaming office towers has prided itself on its prosperity. But suddenly, Stamford has been rocked -- and embarrassed -- by a janitors' strike that has forced the city to pay attention to its often-ignored underside. Using sometimes confrontational tactics, the janitors have thrust their poverty-level wages into Stamford's face and made residents examine the fairness of their earning less than $1,000 a month, less than the rent for most modest apartments here.

headline.main: Stamford Janitors Are Seen, Hoping Wage Plea Is Heard

docs.abstract: Six Stamford, Conn, janitors begin ninth day of hunger strike intended to pressure dozen cleaning contractors to raise their wages from $6.15 an hour to $9 and to give them health insurance (M)
